An intelligent droid used for reconnaissance and scout missions. Probe droids have hundreds of sensors and communication devices for relaying audio, visual, and other data to Imperial starships. They are also programmed with innate curiosity and the order to self-destruct if discovered or attacked. A probot was instrumental in locating the Rebels on Hoth, leading to the Imperial invasion of Echo Base and the Rebellion's painful retreat.
Collect data from remote worlds and scour the galaxy for enemy presence

Arakyd originally designed probe droids to wander space in search of viable <Lookup ("hyper");@hyperspace> routes and undiscovered planets. When the <Lookup ("Galactic Civ");@Galactic Civil War> erupted, Arakyd enhanced the probot's sensors and stealth functions, then sold the droids to the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire> with the promise that the probots would be instrumental in locating Rebel bases. The probots proved successful, and <Lookup ("Vad");@Darth Vader> personally ordered the construction of improved Viper droids for use in his search to find <Lookup ("Skywalker, Luk");@Luke Skywalker>.

Probots are launched from capital ships in small hyperdrive pods. These capsules land on a target planet and release the probot, which then begins a thorough exploration of the world. Probots utilize repulsorlift and thruster units to move over or through virtually every type of terrain, often reaching speeds of about 40 kilometers per hour. While traveling, they employ acoustic, electromagnetic, motive, seismic, and olfactory sensors to detect any signs of habitation. Their array of devices includes optical cameras, zoom imagers, infrared scopes, magnetic imagers, radar and sonar transceivers, and radiation meters. Four manipulator arms and a high-torque grasping arm allow the probot to take samples from the planet. Retractable sensor probes can be extended from the probot's body to provide detailed scans of objects.

Probots search endlessly for signs of life and report their findings to Imperials via restricted Imperial HoloNet communication frequencies. When they encounter life-forms, probots seldom attack, although they are equipped with a single <Lookup ("blaster");@blaster>. Rather, they observe until they are spotted and attacked, at which point they promptly self-destruct.

As the Galactic Civil War intensified, the basic probot design spawned the efficient Hunter-Killer probot. At 150 meters tall, they are among the largest combat droids ever produced. H-K probots are deployed for Imperial customs inspections, blockade enforcement, and pursuit and detainment operations. It operates best in deep space, where it scans starships for signs of smuggling or other crimes. A powerful tractor beam allows the H-K probot to pull a target starship into an internal security chamber within the droid's belly. The chamber measures 30 meters by 10 meters and can hold most freighters. Two quad blasters and a pair of ion cannons located in the hold will activate if the captured ship attempts to flee.

Early designs for the probot included a model with a large radar dish on its head. Later versions depicted a more streamlined droid.

Two models were required to create the probot seen in [The Empire Strikes Back]. For location shooting in Norway, ILM constructed a full-scale probot, which stood 2.4 meters tall with its antenna fully extended. A smaller model, used for stop-motion photography on a miniature set, reached a height of only 63 centimeters.

Probots are armed with concealed blasters for self-defense.

Probot concept art by Ralph McQuarrie.
Comparison of the longer and shorter arms used on the probot model.

An unpainted prototype model, with large radar dish.

Visual effects supervisor Richard Edlund with two versions of the probot.
The full-scale probot packed for shipping to Norway.

To simulate the probot's smooth movements, the model was placed on tracks.

A general all-purpose droid extremely common throughout the galaxy. Asp droids have hydraulically powered limbs and hundreds of servo-motors. Due to their strength, they make excellent laborers and are often used to load or build starships. Although they have only rudimentary computer brains, they work tirelessly and can perform a wide range of simple duties, including maintenance and repair jobs. Modified Asp droids can also be programmed for combat training exercises.

Industrial Automaton's durable and inexpensive Asp droids serve a variety of functions on hundreds of worlds. Although limited to simple tasks, their duties range from maintenance to sanitation to delivery. They are usually assigned to basic jobs that require very little supervision. Industrial Automaton has produced a number of Asp models, but the ASP-7 is the top-selling variant.

Asp droids have skeletal frames and hydraulic limbs. They are incredibly strong and can easily serve as cargo handlers. An Asp's head unit is equipped with an elementary cognitive module, a single <Lookup ("photorec");@photoreceptor>, two auditory sensors, and a primitive vocabulator capable of producing only two words: "affirmative" and "negative."

An Asp's programming is usually limited to the task at hand. It will work tirelessly, following simple commands, until the job has been completed. However, when unexpected situations arise, the droid generally leaves its task unfinished and returns to its master for further instructions.

Due to their rudimentary design, Asps can easily be modified far beyond their original specifications. A reconfigured Asp might possess an enhanced vocabulator, several fine manipulators, or even an advanced computer brain. Darth Vader's legion of ASP-19s boasted armor plating, augmented reflexes, and detailed fencing programs for use as <Lookup ("lightsa");@lightsaber> training opponents.
Several Asp droids haul comm repeaters for use in Mos Eisley on Tatooine.

Any of a number of utility droids, generally programmed for navigation and starship repair. Astromechs are designated by an "R" unit name, such as "R3" unit or "R4" unit. The most familiar are the R2 units, including Luke Skywalker's loyal R2-D2. Many astromechs are designed to fit into special sockets aboard starfighters such as the Y-wing and X-wing. During flight, they can navigate, access hyperspace coordinates stored in their memory banks, and effect in-flight repairs.
Assist with starship navigation and in-flight repairs

Industrial Automaton's first attempts to create an astromech droid surfaced with the design of the P2 unit. Like future models, the astromech prototype had a rotating head, numerous retractable manipulator arms, and three-wheeled legs. Although large and cumbersome, the droid served well as a maintenance and repair unit for bulk cruisers and similar vessels. Unfortunately, Industrial Automaton became involved in a costly technology-infringement lawsuit and the P2 series was discontinued.

Eventually, Industrial Automaton completed the R1 unit. In order to save costs, the droids were housed in tall, black shells recycled from the Mark II Reactor Drone series. The R1 series comes standard with an advanced Intellex III computer, and the droid was the first astromech with the ability to calculate coordinates for a single <Lookup ("hypers");@hyperspace> jump. R1 units typically serve as technicians aboard capital warships and large freighters.

By far the most successful astromech droid is Industrial Automaton's <Lookup ("R2 uni");@R2> series. The droid is much more compact than its predecessors and equipped with a wide array of tools. Although originally designed as a diagnostic and repair unit, the R2 can also serve as a general utility droid and conduct information retrieval.

The R2 series was manufactured to fit perfectly into standard astromech sockets on military starfighters. Previously, the sockets were reserved for dedicated government models. While situated in the astromech socket, an R2 unit can monitor flight performance, isolate and repair technical problems, and reroute power throughout the shipboard systems. Due to its advanced processor, an R2 can perform over 10,000 operations per second to forecast potential problems. R2s can also store up to 10 sets of hyperspace coordinates and can even perform rudimentary flight maneuvers such as engine start-up and preflight taxiing. Due to its impressive abilities, the Industrial Automaton R2 unit quickly became popular with <Lookup ("Old Rep");@Old Republic> fighter jocks and the public at large.

R2s are programmed with specifications on over 700 different spacecraft configurations. They also have impressive sensor packages that incorporate a full-spectrum transceiver and electromagnetic, heat, motion, and life-form detectors. An extendible video sensor can be used to inspect small spaces. Beneath an R2's shell lurks an array of amazing tools that includes two manipulator arms, an electric arc welder, a circular saw, a holographic projector, an internal cargo compartment, and a fire extinguisher.

Following the success of the R2, Industrial Automaton manufactured the R3 and R4 units. The R3 has a more advanced Intellex V computer programmed with detailed statistics on every vessel in the Old Republic army. It primarily serves gunnery crews, security troopers, and naval chiefs of operation aboard capital warships. It can also be plugged into a starfighter, although it only carries five hyperspace coordinates.

In a successful attempt to sell droids to <Lookup ("Outer Rim");@Outer Rim> inhabitants, Industrial Automaton produced the inexpensive yet durable R4 unit. It is programmed with a detailed knowledge of many general-purpose craft, including <Lookup ("landspee");@landspeeders> and <Lookup ("airspee");@airspeeders>, and excels at repairing such vehicles. They are usually found in garages and machine shops, and are only rarely used aboard starfighters as they can only store a single set of hyperspace coordinates.

R5 units represent Industrial Automaton's only real failure in the astromech market. While the most affordable of all astromechs, the R5 series lacks the R2's versatility and the R4's reliability. It also has a tendency to develop annoying personality quirks and is prone to a variety of malfunctions including blown motivators and chronic overheating. Starfighter pilots shunned the droid because it could only store one set of hyperspace coordinates. Because of its limitations, the R5 series was quietly discontinued. The <Lookup ("Rebel All");@Rebel Alliance> did reprogram and rebuild a number of R5 units, and these select droids are now capable of storing up to 10 sets of nav coordinates. <Lookup ("Antilles");@Wedge Antilles> used R5-D2 (nicknamed "Mynock") as his <Lookup ("X-win");@X-wing> astromech during the Battle of <Lookup ("Borl");@Borleias>. However, the droid's chronic shrieking forced Wedge to have Mynock's memory wiped. R5-D2 was subsequently renamed R5-G8, or "Gate."

More recent astromech models include the R6 and R7 units. The R6's design is based largely on the R2, but it has an improved processor and can store up to 12 hyperspace jumps. Because of widespread prosperity caused by the rise of the <Lookup ("New Rep");@New Republic> and huge advances in technology, the R6 proved less expensive to produce than the R2 and thus attracted hordes of consumers.

When <Lookup ("Thrawn");@Grand Admiral Thrawn> took control of the remnants of the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire>, Industrial Automaton dedicated all its efforts to developing a new droid for use in the versatile E-wing starfighter used by New Republic forces. The resulting R7 proved to be the most sophisticated astromech ever constructed. It can store a staggering 15 sets of hyperspace coordinates and is completely protected against power surges and low-level ion blasts. Unfortunately, because the R7 is designed specifically for the E-wing, the droid works poorly in other starfighters.
Luke Skywalker examines an R5 unit.
R2 units are generally more advanced than other droids, like the WED droid shown here.
Astromechs can repair virtually anything, even complex protocol droids.
Suction tubes are used to load R2 units into starfighters.
R2-D2 is placed into the droid socket on Luke's X-wing.
Early production sketches for R2-D2 by Ralph McQuarrie.
A host of R2-D2 units being prepared for filming.
In the first film, the three-legged Artoo had a support pylon connecting the body and side legs.
An R5-D4 unit constructed for [Star Wars].
A look inside Kenny Baker's R2 unit.
Profile view of the R4 model used during filming.
Kenny Baker takes a break while filming [Star Wars].

An advanced healing device which requires submersion in bacta, a gelatinous, translucent mixture of bacterial particles with curative properties. Bacta accelerates the body's natural healing abilities and can erase wounds with very little scarring. While immersed in a bacta tank, the patient must wear a breathing mask and may be prone to convulsions. Luke Skywalker was restored to health in a bacta tank after he was waylaid by a wampa ice creature on Hoth.
Heal wounded individuals through immersion in bacta solution

The Vratix, a species of insectoid aliens native to the planet <Lookup ("Thy");@Thyferra>, created bacta thousands of years before the <Lookup ("Galactic Civ");@Galactic Civil War>. They manufactured the healing salve by combining translucent alayhi with a synthetic liquid chemical known as kavan. In a medical bacta tank, these particles are mixed with a colorless liquid called ambori, which mimics the patient's vital fluids and acts as a nutrient and disinfectant bath. Because bacta has a tendency to spoil when exposed to open air, the ambori is vital to preserve the bacta mixture.

When properly administered, bacta can heal all but the most serious wounds. Wounded limbs can be submerged in small bacta tanks, but patients who have received multiple or life-threatening injuries must be fully immersed. A bacta-tank patient is fitted with a breath mask equipped with a microphone and audio speakers to allow him to communicate with doctors and droids. Throughout the bacta treatment, the healing process is bolstered by medicines, stim-shots, adrenaline boosters, and immunity enhancers.

Two companies, Zaltin and Xucphra, dominate the production and distribution of bacta and bacta tanks. When the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire> rose to power, it forged agreements with both companies to seriously restrict bacta sales. Throughout the Galactic Civil War, the <Lookup ("Rebel All");@Rebel Alliance> suffered from continual bacta shortages. Two and one half years after the <Lookup ("Endor, Bat");@Battle of Endor>, bacta shortages reached all-time highs. As a result, the New Republic launched a campaign to liberate bacta production. The ensuing conflict is commonly known as the <Lookup ("Bacta W");@Bacta War>.  

Patients are fully immersed (with breathing masks) in the expensive liquid, which has been placed in cylindrical rejuvenation or bacta tanks. The bacterial particles actually seek out wounds, then promote amazingly quick tissue growth without scarring. <Lookup ("Palp");@Emperor Palpatine> realized the importance of bacta as a source of even more power and control so he shut down the satellite manufacturing centers and systematically suppressed small manufacturers in favor of the Zaltin and Xucphra corporations. Bacta then fell under the control of a cartel on Thyferra, and the corporations that distributed it became even more powerful than the Emperor intended. Bacta was universally accepted as a safe drug until Ashern rebels contaminated one lot. Millions of people exposed to it became allergic to bacta, particularly the citizens and soldiers on Imperial Center. Later, a Bacta War was fought over control of the healing substance.

The bacta tank seen in [The Empire Strikes Back] was constructed from clear perspex, a material used to manufacture cockpits on pressurized aircraft. It was designed with the cooperation of British Aerospace. The largest of its kind ever built, the huge tank was 7'6" tall, 3'8" in diameter, and held 400 gallons of chlorinated water. Mark Hamill wore a SCUBA regulator while in the tank.
Luke Skywalker is immersed in a bacta tank at Echo Base on Hoth.
Princess Leia and C-3PO watch as Luke is healed.
Luke begins to regain consciousness as his friends look on.
Concept art for the bacta tank by Ralph McQuarrie.
A diver tests the bacta tank used in filming.
Mark Hamill is removed from the tank.
Filming the bacta tank scene required Hamill to be completely immersed in the tank.

A compact, portable life-support system designed to filter the air of unsafe environments and provide the user with oxygen or another breathable gas. Almost all starships, including the [Millennium Falcon], are equipped with several standard breath masks. Worn over the mouth and nose, these units are connected to small oxygen tanks and can protect wearers in poisonous atmospheres or a near vacuum. Breath masks are frequently built into body armor as well, and are a component of the helmets worn by stormtroopers and Darth Vader.
Gandorthral Atmospherics and other medical suppliers

Portable breath masks typically fit over a wearer's nose and mouth. They are frequently equipped with <Lookup ("comlink");@comlinks> or, at the very least, voice amplifiers. Protective goggles or blast helmets can be attached to small molecular hooks on the breath mask.

The Roamer-6 model found aboard the <Lookup ("Mill");@[Millennium Falcon]>, and other similar units, have computerized filters that can be programmed and adjusted to handle the needs of any number of species. Filters on these units are usually expended after only one hour, but inexpensive replacement filters can be snapped into place in just seconds.

Standard breath masks provide no protection from a total vacuum and do not shield users from corrosive atmospheres. In addition, breath masks are only useful for short periods of time, as both their air supplies and filters will eventually be depleted. For individuals who need to stay in a hazardous atmosphere for extended periods, long-term filter breathers offer more sophisticated computers and finer filtration systems. The <Lookup ("Ubese");@Ubese> bounty hunter named <Lookup ("Boushh");@Boushh> used one of these filters to supply vital trace gases when he traveled on human-compatible worlds such as <Lookup ("Tatooi");@Tatooine> and <Lookup ("Corus");@Coruscant>.

A device which flash freezes Tibanna gas for transportation throughout the galaxy. In his attempt to capture Luke Skywalker, Darth Vader had one of Cloud City's carbon-freezing chambers converted to function on humans. Before he would use it on Luke, however, he tested the machine on Han Solo. Han survived the process but remained imprisoned in carbonite for over a year. And, although trapped in a state of suspended animation, he remained conscious and fully aware throughout his terrible ordeal.
Figg and Associates Class Three Carbon-Freezing Chamber
Figg and Associates and other industrial equipment suppliers
Freeze Tibanna gas for shipment to other systems

Carbon-freezing chambers, like those found on <Lookup ("Cloud Cit");@Cloud City>, are notoriously dangerous places to work. They are hot, uncomfortable, and crowded by mazes of machinery and the conduits that pump Tibanna gas, freezing agents, and molten <Lookup ("carboni");@carbonite> into each chamber's freezing pit.

Cloud City is fairly typical of installations that use carbon-freezing chambers. On Cloud City, a giant tractor-beam tube pulls Tibanna gas from <Lookup ("Bespin");@Bespin's> atmosphere. The gas is then pumped through the city's refineries and stabilized at high pressure in press-chem tubes. Shortly before shipment, the Tibanna gas is routed to a carbon-freezing chamber pit, where it is suspended by miniature magnetic fields. After a control casing is moved into place around the gas, scalding liquid carbonite floods the pit. Liquid cooling agents then flash-freeze the carbonite, instantly forming an airtight solid block.

Each carbonite block weighs over 100 kilograms. A hydraulic lift transports the block from the pit, and metal retrieval tongs place the carbonite on a <Lookup ("repuls");@repulsor> sled. While in transport to processing and shipping stations, the Tibanna gas is protected from radiation and extreme temperatures by the carbonite shell.

When used on humans, the carbon-freezing process is akin to torture. The victim is often believed to be trapped in a state of suspended hibernation. However, some evidence suggests that humans trapped in carbonite retain some degree of consciousness. Upon release, the victim experiences many of the symptoms associated with hibernation sickness, including disorientation, temporary blindness, and painful hypersensitivity to loud noises and other sensory input. Liberated victims are also afflicted by a flood of dreams, hallucinations, and memories. Such side effects have been known to cause insanity, but <Lookup ("Solo, H");@Han Solo>, upon being freed from carbonite by <Lookup ("Solo, P");@Princess Leia>, fully recovered from his ordeal.

Han Solo's carbonized form was constructed from fiberglass. Several molds of Harrison Ford's face were made because early casts showed a much more subdued Han. Director Irvin Kershner asked that new molds be created showing Han in complete anguish. Various versions of Ford's face were also created for the "unfreezing" scene in [Return of the Jedi].
The Rebels discover that Han Solo is to be encased in carbonite.
Ugnaughts prepare Han for the carbon-freezing chamber.
Darth Vader, Boba Fett, and a stormtrooper watch as Solo is lowered into the chamber.
The carbonite block imprisoning Han is removed from the carbon-freezing chamber.
Boushh approaches Han's frozen body in Jabba the Hutt's palace.
The carbonite mold constructed for filming.
The cast and crew on the demanding carbon-freezing chamber set.
Another look at the carbonite slab.

A compact communications device consisting of a receiver, transmitter, and power source. The most common form of comlinks are handheld units. Larger comlinks, which are often equipped with scrambling technology, can be worn on the wrist or incorporated into backpacks. Stormtroopers and Rebel pilots typically have comlinks built into their helmets.

In most cases, hand-held and helmet comlinks are audio-only communications devices with a range of about 50 kilometers. Under favorable conditions, many comlinks can reach ships in low orbit. Comlinks can be adjusted to operate on any of the millions of broadcast-frequency and cycle combinations. They also monitor the "Standard Clear Frequencies" used to broadcast civil defense warnings and provide vital information about local laws and nearby medical, educational, and governmental facilities. Military-issue comlinks typically feature a host of encryption tools and can broadcast or receive over secured frequencies.

A device that envelops a vessel or complex in a strong force field meant to keep solid objects at bay and absorb energy. A deflector shield usually consists of two separate protective fields: Ray shielding prevents radiation, laser blasts, and other forms of energy from damaging anything within the deflector shield's range, while particle shielding wards away proton torpedoes and other physical attacks.
KDY ISD-72x Deflector Shield Generator Domes
Kuat Drive Yards and other starship specialists
Generate protective energy fields for starships

Deflector shield generators provide starships with their first line of defense. Although expensive and dependent upon a large power source, deflector shield generators effectively wrap vessels in a protective screen that blocks most incoming attacks. They require less volume than armor plating and can be easily upgraded to handle more intense barrages.

<Lookup ("particle");@Particle shields> are standard equipment aboard almost all starships. They absorb kinetic energy from physical attacks in order to protect against collisions with debris and other ships. The effects of <Lookup ("proton");@proton torpedoes> and concussion missiles are also diverted by particle shields, although the barriers offer no protection against energy attacks such as laser fire. Finally, particle shielding greatly enhances a ship's hull integrity by using energy charges to strengthen the molecular bonds of hull plating. Particle shields are usually kept powered at all times to protect against micrometeors and other small particles. However, a starship must lower its particle shields when launching carried craft or firing physical weapons. With the aid of a computerized system, the shield can be dropped and raised again in an instant.

Starships can be protected from energy attacks, such as blasts from<Lookup ("laser can");@ laser cannons> and <Lookup ("turbo");@turbolasers>, by <Lookup ("ray shie");@ray shields>. Because they consume a great deal of energy, ray shields are only raised when entering combat. The shield energy permeates the starship's hull and protects the vessel through a series of energy layers that can extend up to several centimeters from the craft. Energy shields are incredibly powerful, and simply touching one can be fatal.

Most starfighters and capital ships boast a variety of deflector shield generators to provide both particle and ray shielding.
Deflector shield generators aboard Imperial capital ships are a frequent target for small starfighters.

A handheld viewing apparatus that allows the user to observe distant objects in a variety of lighting conditions and environments. Electrobinoculars have rudimentary computers capable of measuring an object's range, relative size, and other pertinent information, which is then projected onto the device's internal display. The computer also enhances and sharpens the image, and adjusts for wide and zoom angles.
Supply clear images of distant objects

Extremely common throughout the galaxy, electrobinoculars utilize stereoscopic sights and computer-enhanced magnification to view images of distant objects with staggering detail and clarity. Typical units are manufactured with durable plastic casings that protect the optics modules. They are powered by rechargeable energy cells that last up to six months.

Many models boast an instant-focus function, allowing the user to move quickly between objects at varying distances. Screen read-outs can be accessed to determine the distance, relative elevation, and relative and true azimuths of the object. Due to advanced computer-enhanced telescopic lenses, electrobinoculars can provide up to 500 times magnification. Imaging chips adjust and enhance visible light, allowing clear observation of objects in full daylight and near darkness. Electrobinoculars also have automatic dampeners, which negate potentially blinding bursts of light caused by flash grenades, spots lumas, or other similar sources.

Simple control dials on the device allow the user to adjust the zoom, focus, and light compensation. Users can also preprogram up to eight zoom settings.

Many electrobinoculars have data ports capable of feeding images to <Lookup ("hologram");@hologram> recorders, datapads, or other recording tools. They can also be linked to <Lookup ("blaster");@blasters> for long-range attacks. A small number of advanced electrobinoculars have internal hologram and visual recorders capable of storing up to three hour's worth of images. The most expensive of these units can cost over 2,000 credits.

Electrobinoculars are sometimes confused with <Lookup ("macrobi");@macrobinoculars>. Generally less expensive, macrobinoculars lack image enhancement chips and light-adjustment circuitry. However, macrobinoculars are more durable than electrobinoculars and their optics are much less likely to be damaged or thrown out of calibration.
Luke Skywalker spies a group of Tusken Raiders using his electrobinoculars.
Electrobinoculars prop used in [The Empire Strikes Back].

A compact, boxy droid that ambles about on two stocky legs. A power droid's sole purpose is to serve as an energy source for machinery and other droids in areas where permanent power generators are nonexistent or unreliable. Power droids lack logic circuits and only obey simple voice commands. On rare occasions, they can be programmed to run rudimentary diagnostic checks on other droids. When active, GNK power droids make a strange, guttural noise.
Serve as an active power supply for vehicles and other droids

While a variety of companies manufacture power droids, almost all of these units share the same basic characteristics. Power droids lack exterior manipulator appendages, move about on stumpy legs, and communicate through a series of grunts and gurgles.

A power droid consists of a fusion generator encased in a heavy armored exterior. The droids are incredibly durable, built to survive virtually any disaster, including a radiation conduit breach. In the rare event that the droid begins to overheat or is subjected to extreme temperatures, small relief valves on the outer casing and bases of both feet release vaporizing coolant fluid as steam.

On their exterior shell, power droids have a plug-in port, a visual sensor, and an acoustic signaler capable of droid and computer languages. They also have a sophisticated systems-diagnostic package with a spectrometer and infrared, sonar, and X-ray scanners. While servicing equipment, power droids use their sensors to run detailed safety checks. A power droid will refuse to refuel any item that registers signs of malfunction.

Although rarely noticed, many power droids do have a delicate manipulator arm concealed behind a tiny portal. The arm is only extended for extremely sensitive electronics work. However, power droids are only entrusted with such repairs when droids specifically programmed for such tasks are not available.
A series of GNK droids go about their duties at Echo Base on Hoth.

Any device that produces or broadcasts moving three-dimensional images in real time. Hologram projectors are a common form of communication across the galaxy. Many droids are equipped with rudimentary hologram projectors, while much larger and more advanced projectors are commonly installed aboard capital ships and space stations. Hologram messages can also be recorded, stored on data cards, and replayed continuously.

Most hologram projectors consist of both recording and projecting devices. When a holographic recording is made, the recorder scans the subject via two synchronized imagers. An internal computer combines these recordings to construct a three-dimensional light image complete with color, sound, and motion. <Lookup ("hologram");@Hologram> images recorded in this manner can be stored on crystals, data tapes, and data discs. All three storage devices can be used with any standard hologram projector.

Hologram projectors vary widely in quality. Miniaturized units, such as those installed in <Lookup ("astrome");@astromech droids>, produce images plagued by flickers, sudden color shifts, and other technical glitches.

Hologram projectors have a wide variety of uses throughout the galaxy. Larger units can be used for entertainment, and holographic films, sculptures, and paintings are extremely popular. <Lookup ("Dejar");@Dejarik> and similar games utilize hologram playing pieces projected by hologame boards. More advanced systems create completely immersive environments for use at amusement centers, including Hologram Fun World, which was briefly owned by <Lookup ("Calr");@Lando Calrissian>.

Military applications of hologram technology are limitless. Three-dimensional technical read-outs and tactical maps allow military leaders to plan their missions and battles with great detail. Military simulators use hologram projectors to train pilots for starfighter combat.
Artwork depicting the hologram display of Endor.

An access tool issued to Imperial officers for security clearance aboard battle stations and at military installations. Each cylinder contains a number of computer codes granting the officer entrance to sensitive areas commensurate with his or her rank. At major checkpoints, the cylinders are inserted into scomp links to interface with a centralized computer, which then clears or denies the officer's access request.
Denote rank and provide officers with security clearance codes

Imperial code cylinders are among the most common security tools employed by the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire>. Each Imperial installation is divided into a variety of sectors, each separated from the others by security checkpoints. Secured areas can only be accessed by Imperial officers, who prove their identity and rank by inserting individualized code cylinders into a scomp link at the checkpoint. The scomp link determines if the officer has the proper clearance before granting or denying access.

Because each code cylinder permits access to only specific areas, many high-ranking officers carry up to four of the devices. Code cylinders can also be used to access information from computer systems. To prevent thieves from using code cylinders, some checkpoints may be equipped with retinal scanners or voice-recognition devices, which are used in conjunction with the cylinders. Data discs worn on an officer's belt or hat also carry vital information about the Imperial's identity and rank.

A robot designed by the Imperial Security Bureau for use in questioning prisoners. The black sphere is equipped with a wide range of probes, sensors, and needles, as well as a personal repulsorlift and a detailed understanding of human and alien anatomy. Most frightening is the interrogator droid's artificial intelligence, which allows it to analyze each individual's physical and chemical weaknesses. Through prolonged torture, chemical injections, and other methods, the droid exploits these weaknesses until the victim breaks.
Extract sensitive information from prisoners through torture

Commonly known as torture droids, Imperial interrogator droids are among the most heinous inventions conceived by the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire>. Simple in its design, the IT-O interrogation unit is a glossy black sphere less than a meter tall. It hovers above the ground on low-powered <Lookup ("repuls");@repulsors> and communicates through a rudimentary vocabulator. The droid's surface is a testament to its function: its tools include a sonic torture device, an electroshock assembly, a grasping claw, a laser scalpel, power shears, and an oversized hypodermic injector syringe. Internal reservoirs store a host of liquid chemicals, including the truth serum Bavo Six, which are dispensed through the fearsome needle. The drugs lower pain thresholds, stimulate cooperation, and trigger hallucinations.

Interrogator droids are also equipped with optic sensors and audio receptors that transmit a victim's contorted face and anguished screams to the droid. The droid's programming encompasses medicine, psychology, surgery, and humanoid biology. Vital-sign monitors predict the onset of unconsciousness, which the droid seeks to avoid at all costs. A recorder unit on the IT-O preserves any confessions shrieked during the torture session. The droid's advanced sensors allow it to evaluate the confessor's truthfulness based on heart rates, muscle tension, and voice patterns.

The Empire often employed torture droids to question captured Rebels. However, <Lookup ("Solo, P");@Princess Leia> managed to survive her encounter with an IT-O and a psychic probe by <Lookup ("Vad");@Darth Vader> without revealing the location of the hidden Rebel base. As a child, Leia was trained to resist torture and other forms of interrogation in order to protect the sensitive information she possessed as part of the Royal House of <Lookup ("Alder");@Alderaan>.

In early McQuarrie sketches of the torture droid, the robot possessed arms with long, clawlike manipulators. In [A New Hope], the upper half of the interrogator droid model was a repainted R2 unit head, while the lower half was a painted Lucite sphere. The model was moved with the aid of a crane, hidden just out of the camera's field of vision.

1
tech\devices\sounds\ tortdrd.sad Interrogator Droid Sound Effect
Concept art of the interrogator droid and Princess Leia.

The common sublight drive found on virtually every starship throughout the galaxy. Ion engines produce thrust by projecting a stream of charged particles through the engine's exhaust port. Ion engines come in a variety of configurations, but one of the most successful designs has been the twin ion engine (or TIE) made popular by the quick and agile Imperial TIE fighters.
Corellian Engineering Corporation Advanced Ion Engine Block
Provide starships with sublight space travel

Ion drives are extremely common sublight drives employed to transport starships from planets and through space. During space battles, all starships engage their sublight drives.

An ion engine draws power from local power cells or on-board generators. It then creates an internal controlled fusion reaction. The reaction produces charged particles, which are channeled through the ion engine. When the particles are ejected from the engine, they propel the starship. Some ion engines can be converted to use heavy metals, liquid reactants, and other substances as fuel.

Any private inner sanctum used by Jedi Knights and Dark Jedi to reflect on the future, rejuvenate their inner strength, and improve their subtle mental powers. The most well-known meditation chamber was built for Darth Vader aboard his Super Star Destroyer, the [Executor]. Befitting the Dark Lord of the Sith, the chamber was an ominous, spherical construct that opened by splitting into two halves like some gaping maw. The pressurized enclosure also included a device that allowed Vader to quickly remove and replace his helmet and breath mask.
Establish regulated and comfortable environment for meditation

Meditation chambers are as unique as the individuals who make use of the devices. It appears that some powerful Jedi, such as <Lookup ("Keno");@Obi-Wan Kenobi> and <Lookup ("Yoda");@Yoda>, had no need for meditation chambers. However, the <Lookup ("Dark Lord");@Dark Lord of the Sith>, <Lookup ("Vad");@Darth Vader>, built a specialized meditation chamber with a comfortable reclining chair, a <Lookup ("comlink");@comlink> and visual display, and a mechanical device for quickly removing and replacing his helmet and breath mask. The sphere was completely pressurized and climate-controlled.

About 5,000 years earlier, the Sith Lord <Lookup ("Sadow");@Naga Sadow> made use of a huge meditation sphere. During his war against the <Lookup ("Old Rep");@Old Republic>, Sadow plotted his moves and controlled his forces from the floating orb, which also served as his personal starship. The sphere allowed him to control and focus his awesome powers throughout the chaotic battles that followed his invasion of the Old Republic. Ultimately, Sadow was defeated by the combined might of <Lookup ("Teta, Emp");@Empress Teta's> army, the forces of the Old Republic, and a contingent of <Lookup ("Jedi kn");@Jedi Knights>.
Darth Vader sits in his meditation chamber aboard the [Executor].
The meditation chamber set during filming.
A scarred Darth Vader waits for filming to continue.

A compact droid designed to transport sensitive documents throughout Imperial installations. To collect and deliver data, mouse droids are equipped with retractable manipulator arms. They are also lightly armored, programmed with a host of evasive maneuvers, and extremely agile. Although mouse droids most often travel in pairs, they can also be linked to form long trains. In order to protect their cargo, mouse droids flee all potential threats, and they are thus often wrongly viewed as cowardly and easily frightened.
Deliver sensitive documents to Imperial officers

The MSE-6 droid was originally manufactured by Rebaxan Columni, a now-defunct <Lookup ("Chadra");@Chadra-Fan> company. Originally intended to serve as a general-purpose droid, the Chadra-Fan engineers designed the droid to resemble a diminutive pet animal from their homeworld. Unfortunately, the droid's personality and chirping language reminded consumers of vermin instead. Many of the MSE-6 droids were returned to the company, and Rebaxan Columni collapsed.

As the company folded, Rebaxan offered the remaining MSE-6 droids to the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire> at an incredible discount. At the time, the Imperial Navy was suffering from a shortage of droids due to rapid expansion. As a result, MSE-6 droids found their way onto virtually every Imperial starship and installation throughout the galaxy.

A MSE-6 droid's programming is determined by a single modular circuit matrix. Such matrices can only hold one task, but they are cheap and easy to install. In fact, MSE-6 droids are often reprogrammed by other mouse droids assigned to replace matrices. Common MSE skill matrices include elementary repair, security, janitorial clean-up, and basic computer programming. While in the Empire's service, the droids are often programmed to serve as messengers. They can also be found leading troops through the winding corridors of large installations, such as the <Lookup ("Death");@Death Star>.

A MSE-6 droid has a heavy manipulator arm for lifting and moving large objects. Another delicate arm is used to make intricate repairs and perform other sensitive jobs. Both arms are retractable and generally remain hidden within the MSE-6 droid's outer shell. Other devices include an auditory sensor, an electro-photoreceptor, and a miniature holocam.

When the droid is acting as a courier, a small compartment on top of the mouse droid stores sealed orders and sensitive documents. This compartment can only be opened with an authorized voice-code.
The mouse droid in [Star Wars] was a small, remote-controlled model. The droid reappeared throughout the trilogy.

Any biomechanical device used to replace body parts ranging from internal organs to limbs. Prosthetic replacements are connected to organic tissue via a complex synthenet neural interface, which provides the recipient with control and sensation. External replacements are covered by synth-flesh to emulate actual organic tissue. A great deal of Darth Vader's ravaged body was supported by prosthetic replacements, and Luke Skywalker was fitted with a prosthetic hand after losing his own during his first battle with Vader.
Zaltin and other major medical suppliers
Replace a lost or damaged limb with cybernetic implant
Varies according to size of original limb
Varies with limb type and size

An area of medical technology spurred by the carnage of the <Lookup ("Clone War");@Clone Wars>, the replacement of body parts with lifelike replicas reached a high level of refinement during the <Lookup ("Galactic Civ");@Galactic Civil War>. Prosthetic replacements allow the injured to see through artificial eyes, feel and grip with artificial hands, and run with artificial legs. Mechanical hearts pump blood and other replacement organs handle important bodily functions. Most prosthetics use synthenet neural interfaces to provide recipients with full control of replaced limbs. In order to make a prosthetic replacement appear natural, synth-flesh covers the appendage.

In the radio drama adaptation of [The Empire Strikes Back], the medical droid explains the process for connecting a prosthetic limb. He tells Luke, "I have to locate all the nerve endings in your wrist precisely, in order to fit your powered prosthetic hand." The droid also reveals that "other procedures will become available for the treatment of your injury" once the Rebel fleet has been able to organize a complete medical center. By this account, Luke's prosthetic hand was designed to serve as a temporary replacement.
A behind-the-scenes look at the climactic end to the Cloud City lightsaber duel.

Any of a number of programmable automatons, often floating spheres equipped with relatively harmless blasters and an array of sensors. The most common model is the Marksman-H combat remote, used extensively by sharpshooters to hone their skills. While traveling aboard the [Millennium Falcon], Luke Skywalker borrowed Han Solo's Marksman-H to begin his lightsaber training. The Empire also deploys modified remotes known as seekers, which are armed with deadly blasters and can be programmed to hunt down and kill specific targets.
Industrial Automaton and other droid manufacturers
Aid in target practice and melee combat training

Remotes are simple droids without independent initiative that can only act on orders given by their owners. Typically, remotes are programmed to serve as combat training tools. In this capacity, the remote's on-board computer houses dozens of combat drills. During a training session, the trainee sets his <Lookup ("blaster");@blaster> to emit light only, while the remote's weapons are set at stun. As the training sessions intensify, the remote begins to move more quickly and attack with more intense bursts of energy. In the most extreme cases, the remote's stun blasts can render the trainee unconscious.

Remotes can also be programmed to serve as microphones, cargo lifters, baggage carriers, and long-range surveillance units. The <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire's> "seeker" units are modified remotes designed to seek out and kill Imperial enemies. Seekers have a pair of blasters, an incredibly sensitive sensor suite, and the ability to interface with almost any computer system.

The remote model used in [A New Hope] was built to scale and measured 15 cm in diameter. It was rotated by a small motor during blue screen filming.

Several additional remotes appear in the novelization of [The Empire Strikes Back] and are used by Yoda to train Luke. These remotes, known as "seekers," are much more aggressive than Han Solo's training tool and attack in a small pack. On at least one occassion, their blasts render Luke unconscious.
The remote model was rotated by a small motor during filming.
A close look at the remote model.

A circular device attached to a droid to override its motor functions and enslave the robot to the will of its master. A restraining bolt monitors the droid's activity, ensuring the machine's loyalty and preventing it from wandering away. A restraining bolt can also be keyed to a "caller," a handheld control unit used to instantly summon or paralyze the droid. Jawas affixed restraining bolts to both R2-D2 and C-3PO before the droids were sold to Owen Lars on Tatooine.
Prevent droids from acting against the wishes of their masters

Restraining bolts, vital to the control of droids, are usually mounted on a special restraining bolt mount located on most droids. When this mount is damaged or unavailable, however, the bolt can be magnetically attached directly to the surface of the droid. In either case, the bolt can override the droid's functions.

With a handheld <Lookup ("caller");@caller>, a droid's owner can summon, paralyze, or locate the automaton. Because most droids are programmed to be obedient and perform specific tasks, restraining bolts are seldom necessary. However, spirited droids with a tendency to wander away from their assignments may find their restraining bolts activated with great regularity.

A device that produces a modified force field capable of immobilizing and capturing objects. Tractor beams are widely used to guide ships safely into landing bays, move salvage through the space lanes, collect stranded craft, and reposition space stations. However, Imperial starships utilize tractor beam projectors to paralyze their prey and pull the helpless craft within range for boarding or complete destruction.
Custom-Built Imperial Death Star Tractor Beam Projector
Phylon and other major starship and space station manufacturers
Generate tractor beam for capturing or guiding starships

Tractor beam projectors have a number of uses throughout the galaxy. On freighters and similar ships, tractor beams can be employed to move cargo modules. In hangar bays and spaceports, they ensure safe landings by leading vessels into landing bays.

Military tractor beams have become a valuable component of almost every combat engagement. Imperial <Lookup ("star des");@Star Destroyers> use their beams to capture fleeing enemy ships, while Rebels deploy tractor beams to rescue pilots who have ejected from their starfighters.

Tractor beams have difficulty targeting fast and maneuverable starships. They also require a great deal of space and maintenance. The largest tractor beam emplacements found aboard Star Destroyers require crews of up to 10 operators and technicians.

For large space stations, such as the <Lookup ("Death");@Death Star>, tractor beams are often coupled to a main reactor to provide the device with a steady stream of energy. However, if the tractor beam's connection to the reactor is severed at any of the coupling sites, the beam becomes completely inoperative. On the first Death Star, the tractor beam that captured the <Lookup ("Mill");@[Millennium Falcon]> was coupled to the reactor at seven separate locations. <Lookup ("Keno");@Obi-Wan Kenobi> disabled the force field by simply shutting down one of those sites.

In [Star Wars], Obi-Wan Kenobi deactivates the Death Star's tractor beams by accessing a terminal high above the space station's power trench. To complete this scene, live-action footage was shot in England and composited with matte art by Harrison Ellenshaw. Although Kenobi (Alec Guinness) appears to be several stories above the Death Star's reactor core, he was actually only a few feet off the ground.

A tall, cylindrical device used to coax moisture from the air on Tatooine and other dry, desert worlds. The primary tool of moisture farmers, a vaporator employs "chilling bars" to cool the surrounding air. Moisture eventually accumulates on the chilling bars and drips into a collection chamber, where it is then pumped into an underground storage tank. Moisture farmers rarely profit from their work, usually collecting just enough water for their own personal use.
Collect water from air on dry worlds

A vaporator typically stands between three and five meters tall, and the bulk of the device consists of multiple refrigerated cylinders. The unit emits a low-power ionized field as it cools the air, causing condensation in even the most arid environments. A control computer in the vaporator automatically adjusts ionization and refrigeration levels to compensate for wind speed and changing temperatures. The entire structure is powered by energy cells charged by retractable solar panels. A typical vaporator on <Lookup ("Tatooi");@Tatooine> can collect about 1.5 liters of water per day, provided it is at least 250 meters from all other vaporators.

Vaporators communicate using a primitive binary programming language. Because of this, a droid is often needed to converse with the device. A vaporator is also extremely susceptible to sand, which has a tendency to collect in the device's lubricants and potentially disable the refrigeration unit. As a result, moisture farmers often spend much of their time simply removing sand from their vaporators.
A single vaporator rests outside Obi-Wan Kenobi's house.
A series of moisture vaporators spread across the Lars moisture farm.

The starship engine responsible for accelerating a vehicle to faster-than-lightspeed velocities. The hyperdrive engine, which is powered by efficient fusion generators, essentially propels a starship into the alternate dimension known as hyperspace, where the normal laws of space and time no longer apply. Through hyperspace, vehicles can cross vast distances of space in an instant. However, hyperdrives require guidance from advanced astrogation computers to prevent fatal collisions while traveling at such staggering speeds.
Supply starships with the ability to travel through hyperspace

The invention of the hyperdrive, some 25,000 years before the <Lookup ("Galactic Civ");@Galactic Civil War>, is often credited with the <Lookup ("Old Rep");@Old Republic's> growth and expansion. Hyperdrive technology, which allows starships to travel between countless worlds in a relatively short time, provided the Old Republic with the means to explore and colonize much of the known galaxy.

Although hyperspace travel has become a common form of space travel, it still poses many dangers. Objects in realspace cast mass shadows into hyperspace. Any ship striking a mass shadow in hyperspace is instantly destroyed. Fortunately, starships have navigational computers designed to calculate safe travel routes through hyperspace. These paths take ships around stars, planets, stray asteroids, and other hazards. However, once a ship enters hyperspace, it cannot change course.

Hyperdrive engines are generally rated by "classes," and the lower the class, the faster the hyperdrive. Most civilian ships have Class Three or higher hyperdrives, while military ships boast Class Two or Class One engines. Truly exceptional ships, such as Dash Rendar's <Lookup ("Outrid");@[Outrider]> and <Lookup ("Solo, H");@Han Solo's> <Lookup ("Mill");@[Millennium Falcon]> have Class 0.75 or Class 0.5 hyperdrives.

A normally innocuous device originally designed to analyze metals. A scan grid collects data on a substance's thermal and magnetic properties by applying a series of electrical charges to the subject. The machine then observes and records the effects of these surges, and later uses this information to deduce the metal's true nature. While normally harmless, Darth Vader modified one of Cloud City's scan grids for use in torturing Han Solo, subjecting the smuggler to several rounds of excruciating electrical shocks.
Figg and Associates and other industrial equipment suppliers
Analyze magnetic and thermal properties of metals

Scan grids are an important element of any mining colony, as they allow the miners to determine the exact nature of any ore. The electrical charges emitted by the scan grid infuse the metal in question, collecting data that can conclusively identify the substance. When applied to bare flesh, these electrical impulses cause a great deal of pain.

A propulsion unit common in land and atmospheric aircraft. Based on antigravity technology, a repulsorlift engine produces a field that acts in opposition to a planet's gravity, causing the equipped vehicle to hover above the ground. Landspeeders, airspeeders, speeder bikes, and twin-pod cloud cars all rely on repulsorlift engines, as does the engineering marvel Cloud City. Starships and fighters also have repulsorlift engines for use while traveling or landing within a planet's atmosphere.
Bespin Motors Storm IV Repulsorlift Engine
Provide vehicles with antigravity field for movement within an atmosphere

The most common form of antigravity drive, repulsorlift engines can be found on a wide range of craft, including <Lookup ("landspee");@landspeeders>, <Lookup ("snowspee");@snowspeeders>, <Lookup ("sail");@sail barges>, and <Lookup ("twin");@cloud cars>. Almost all starships utilize repulsorlift engines for planetary landings and atmospheric flight.

Most repulsorlifts are powered by fusion generators and generate an antigravity field which repels against a planet's gravity. Although drives vary, the most powerful repulsorlift engines can carry a vehicle into low orbit or propel the craft at speeds over 1,000 kilometers per hour. Repulsorlift engines do not function in space.

A droid programmed to understand millions of languages and cultures in order to serve as an interpreter, administrative assistant, and diplomatic aide. Protocol droids such as C-3PO are humanoid in appearance and are allowed to develop independent personalities. They are usually owned by high-ranking military officers, royalty, or the wealthy. Aside from their language skills, protocol droids can be programmed to understand and converse with computers and other machines, decipher codes and technical data, and even teach.
Serve as administrative assistant, diplomatic aide, interpreter, and advisor

Protocol droids owe much of their success to their advanced SyntheTech AA-1 VerboBrain. A highly advanced neural network, the VerboBrain is an elite cognitive module designed to produce flawless interpreters and impeccable diplomats. With an intact VerboBrain, a protocol droid can develop true emotions and a complex personality.

A protocol droid's primary functions include interpretation, but also encompass etiquette, decorum, customs, religious rituals, and even table manners for millions of distinct cultures across the galaxy. Standard protocol droids boast an understanding of over six million languages, including obscure dialects and a variety of droid communications. The 3PO's advanced vocabulator allows it to perfectly reproduce any sound.

3PO units are typically housed in humanoid body shells of gold, silver, or white. They possess photoreceptors, auditory pickups, olfactory sensors, broadband antenna receivers, microwave detectors, and a primary circuit breaker. Because of their physical complexity, 3PO droids require frequent oil baths to maintain their joints and couplings.

Many of the parts used for the protocol droids throughout the trilogy were also used for other humanoid droids, including the servant droid seen in the Jawa sandcrawler, the black Death Star droid, and 4-LOM.
C-3PO (right) and U-3PO aboard the [Tantive IV].
K-3PO monitors one of Echo Base's com-scan displays.
K-3PO is programmed with a knowledge of military tactics.
K-3PO and C-3PO in one of Echo Base's chilly corridors.
Ralph McQuarrie sketch of Threepio's head.
A look at the back of the C-3PO costume.
An actor in a protocol droid suit is rolled into position for filming.
The protocol droids on the set during filming of [Star Wars].
The droids pose during filming of [The Empire Strikes Back].

Small, floating droids equipped with repulsorlift engines, an array of sensors, and a full complement of communications devices. Patrol droids, which are used primarily by Imperial forces, are programmed to sweep cities and settlements in search of wanted outlaws and any signs of criminal activity. Their memory banks are loaded with data on known Rebels, smugglers, escaped slaves, and spies. They also carefully monitor the power levels and wavelengths of local communication signals in order to enforce Imperial communications laws.
Imperial Sentry Mark IV Patrol Droid
Provide general surveillance in populated areas

Mark IV patrol droids are essentially floating sensors suites. Repulsorlift engines keep the droids aloft at all times and provide them with agile movement. The droids can reach altitudes of 10 meters. While flying about in search of the <Lookup ("Empire");@Empire's> enemies, the droid employs sensor clusters located at its front, rear, and top. It can, quite literally, see in all directions at once. Among its many sensors are electromagnetic and infrared detectors, a host of visual scanners, miniature <Lookup ("macrobin");@macrobinoculars> with a built-in holorecording device, and a broadband antenna/receiver that communicates solely on coded Imperial alert frequencies.

Patrol droids have detailed databanks filled with historical data on law enforcement, as well as the full text of the exhaustive Imperial Legal Code. Local forces can also upload supplementary lists of regional statutes and topographical maps of patrol areas. Patrol droids also carry information on all individuals wanted by the Empire and the local government. In some locales, the patrol droids are fitted with low-power <Lookup ("blaster");@blasters>. 

Patrol droids are programmed to report anything illegal. They therefore can become a nuisance in areas where out-of-date laws are not regularly updated and purged from the droid's memory banks. While their personality programming is minimal, patrol droids can develop strange quirks if not subjected to regular memory wipes.
A Mark IV patrol droid, nicknamed "Face," confers with a sandtrooper stationed in Mos Eisley.

A space capsule used by passengers and crew to abandon starships in emergencies. Once launched, an escape pod collects data on nearby planets, then uses its simple drive system to enter the atmosphere of the nearest hospitable world. As it nears the planet's surface, the pod employs a repulsorlift drive and maneuvering jets to facilitate a safe landing. While carrying the Death Star plans, R2-D2 eluded Imperial forces by commandeering one of the [Tantive IV]'s escape pods, thereby ensuring the Alliance's victory at the Battle of Yavin.
Corellian Engineering Corporation Class-6 Escape Pod
Provide short-term transportation away from disabled vessels

Escape pods, which are found aboard virtually all starships, range in size from small capsules capable of holding only one passenger to huge lifeboats that can carry over a dozen individuals. The interior of each escape pod is spartan, as the vehicles are designed to be used for only a few hours at most. A standard pod consists of a simple piloting station and padded gee-couches.

After an escape pod is launched, sensor systems on the capsule provide atmosphere, radiation, and gravity information about nearby worlds. The escape pod's on-board computers can process this data and use its simple drive systems to enter the atmosphere of the nearest hospitable planet. Upon landing, the escape pod employs parachutes, repulsorlift drives, maneuvering jets, or flotation devices to facilitate a safe touchdown.

Upon landing, the passengers can access two week's worth of rations, including food, water, survival shelters, med-pacs, <Lookup ("breath");@breath masks>, glow rods, <Lookup ("comlin");@comlinks>, and a limited-range communications transceiver. An escape pod's supplies may also include a civilian hunting <Lookup ("blaster");@blaster>, and the shell of the craft can be used as a temporary shelter during emergencies. 

Escape pods have a limited fuel supply meant to deliver the capsule to the closest hospitable planet. However, in the event that the pod is ejected into a region of the galaxy devoid of suitable worlds, the capsule can float through space awaiting rescue. 

An escape pod of <Lookup ("Corellian En");@Corellian> design is often credited with saving the galaxy from the <Lookup ("Death");@Death Star>:  <Lookup ("R2-D2");@R2-D2>, carrying the Death Star plans, escaped Imperial forces by commandeering one of the <Lookup ("Tant");@[Tantive IV]'s> six-being escape pods.

Joe Johnston completed the original concept sketches for the [Tantive IV]'s escape pod. The completed model measured 21 x 21 x 44 cm. During filming, the model was supported by a blue pylon in front of a blue screen and slightly rotated. Later, the shot of the pod was composited with a matte painting of Tatooine, a starfield, and other elements. The shots involving the escape pod were among the first completed by ILM.
The escape pod containing R2-D2 and C-3PO hurtles toward Tatooine.
Escape pods have only rudimentary engines designed to deliver the craft to the nearest planet.
Storyboard art depicting the escape pod.
The pod release, from a launch bay perspective.
The escape pod model under construction.
A look at the engines on the pod model.
Profile view of the pod model.
During filming, the pod was mounted on a pylon and slightly rotated.
The pod during blue screen photography.
